Emergency Response

The site has a 67-member strong Emergency Response Team that is HAZWOPER certified, trained in Confined Space Entry Rescue, certified in First Aid and CPR, have EMT's, and a Fire Brigade. The team participates in training every quarter, some on-site and some off-site.  Training also includes regular drills to test the site's response capabilities. The results of these drills are communicated to all employees including evacuation plans for non-responders.  The site also owns and maintains a wide selection of emergency response equipment.  The site works jointly with the Local Emergency Planning Committee (LEPC) including a myriad of Virginia's Emergency Response specialists including the hospital staff, HAZMAT teams, local fire and police, and many other experts in emergency response in the state.  The onsite training requirements are determined by the ERT management team and the training is performed by the ERT manager, outside agencies, and trained ERT members. Safety Philosophy

Management of the Suffolk Solenis Site is guided by the principals found in Responsible Care. The American Chemistry Council (ACC) Responsible Care Management System (RCMS) is composed of six codes of management practice found in the ACC's Association's Responsible Care initiative.  Three of the codes are particularly relevant to this discussion which are, Process Safety (PS); Employee Health and Safety (H&S); and: Community Awareness and Emergency Response (CAER).
 
Process safety oversite is managed by the site's Process Safety Management (PSM) Committee, which is comprised of employees from each production area, engineering and maintenance, Senior Management as well as environmental, health and safety personnel.  The committee monitors PSM issues, hosts training activities and performs PSM audits.  
Oversite and management of the elements of Process Safety are the responsibility of site employees who have been designated as a Subject Matter Experts (SME). It is their responsibility to implement and manage the program. The site's SMEs review the status of their element annually and present these findings to the PSM committee through formally scheduled presentations.  These documented reviews consist of a comparison between the site's written health and safety program to regulatory requirements, and other identified best practices.

 General Manufacturing Process

XD1878 is a classified as a biocide and as such a Critical Environmental hazard does exist. Care should be taken when working with the product. XD1878 is used as a precursor for biocide. Refer to Standard Operating Procedure XD-05, raw materials for information about special product handling.

The XD plant uses a batch process that is controlled via a process control system. All charges and transfers are automated.

The process begins with a pre-charge amount of 5,000 lbs. of DMW from the previous batch. The reaction vessel is then inerted with nitrogen. Once inerted, DMW is added in a separate charge of 4,600 lbs. to reach the total water set point of 9,600 lbs. Ammonium Hydroxide is charged into the vessel in quantities as stated on the operator’s recipe sheet. When 80% of the charged volume of ammonia is complete, and a starting temperature of 15°C is reached, carbon dioxide is charged into the vessel. The polymerization of XD1878 is an exothermic reaction and, as such, the temperature in the vessel is maintained at a set point 53°C by circulating the contents of the reactor through the heat exchanger until the reaction is complete. The product is then cooled down to less than 40°C and sodium hydroxide solution is charged into the vessel. A sample is taken to QC lab and, once approved, is then transferred to the storage tank (ST121 or ST119).

XD1878 Process Description (Ammonia)

The XD plant is a closed system production line for the purpose of synthesising ammonium carbamate, referred to as XD1878.

The main components of the XD plant are the reaction vessel (VE305) and a scrubbing system (SC402). 28% Ammonium Hydroxide, referred to as ammonia, is fed from a dedicated storage tank (ST501). Demineralized Water (DMW) is fed from a shared storage tank with the CPAM plant. 50% Sodium Hydroxide, referred to as caustic, is fed from the site side caustic ring located in Works 1. Carbon Dioxide is metered from a storage tank (tank number) located in the TFA extension. In addition, there are pumps, automated valves, and heat exchangers in the plant.

 The reaction vessel (VE305) is made of stainless steel and is equipped with an agitator. The vessel is not rated for any pressure within the vessel above atmospheric. Around the vessel is a circulation system with a heat exchanger that can feed chilled water or steam to adjust the temperature as is required. Along the bottom of the vessel is a sparge diffuser for the addition of nitrogen or carbon dioxide. The bottom of the vessel also has sub surface dip tube for the addition of ammonia. The vessel has a capacity of 3800 USG.

aterials. The material is unloaded into one of three storage tanks in rotation, which are never filled to more than 80% capacity. The tanks are equipped with the following alarms; high and low level, high and low pressure and high and high/high temperatures. 
Storage tank levels can be monitored and controlled remotely by production personnel and observed via a CCV. 

Accidental Release Prevention Measures

The highest probability of a release of acrylonitrile would occur during the unloading process, but the likelihood of a significant release is extremely remote based on the design, construction, operation and testing associated with acrylonitrile offloading.  

Prevention measures include the following:

A derailer is placed on the railroad track in front of the railcar being offloaded, which prevents any other railcar mistakenly placed on the track from reaching the offloading car.
Transfer hoses are inspected, and pressure tested before each offload.
The initial step in the off-loading process is to pressurize the rail car and the transfer line to the pump. In this manner issues with equipment would be detected quickly and a minimal amount would be released.
During the entire railcar offloading process, the rail car, the offloading line and the storage tank diked areas are monitored by remote tilt/zoom cameras from the process control room which is manned throughout the off-loading operation. If required, the off-loading process can be halted remotely from the control room
An acrylonitrile detector is mounted beneath the offloading station that would detect a vapor release to atmosphere. There is also a sensor in the diked area to provide early warning of a leak. 
Each storage tank is equipped with an independent high-level shutoff mechanism to prevent overfilling.  
Should a leak occur, a remotely operated shutdown switch is in place, which would close all transfer lines, shut down the transfer pump and close the storage tank fill lines.

Facility Description

Solenis LLC, formally BASF Corporation in Suffolk Virginia was established in 1983 as an organic chemical manufacturer. The plant utilizes acrylic chemistry to manufacture water soluble polymers for use in the water treatment, mining, and paper industries. There is also on-site warehouse that manages the site's distribution activities. The facility can receive raw materials in containers by rail or truck. Finished goods are packaged for shipment in various sized containers or delivered by truck or rail. 

The site covers 225 acres on the west side of Wilroy Road, ½ mile north of the Wilroy Industrial Park and east of the Nansemond River. Of the 225 acres the production facility occupies 35 acres and the remainder is utilized for agriculture or undeveloped.

RMP Chemicals on Site

There are several chemicals on site that are listed under the RMP rule: acrylonitrile, propane, acetylene, sulfur dioxide and ammonia hydroxide.  All but acrylonitrile and Ammonia hydroxide are stored at levels below the RMP threshold.  Acrylonitrile is used in the manufacture of acrylamide, the site's primary raw material.  

Process Description

Production of acrylamide monomer from acrylonitrile began in 1997 with a process called catalytic hydration.  This process was discontinued in September of 2013 and was replaced by a biocatalytic process in July 2014. The new operation is a batch process that operates under ambient pressure and temperatures.
